      92                 :             :  *  point the OVERLOADED_PEER_TX_DELAY kicks in. */
      93                 :             : static constexpr int32_t MAX_PEER_TX_REQUEST_IN_FLIGHT = 100;
      94                 :             : /** Maximum number of transactions to consider for requesting, per peer. It provides a reasonable DoS limit to
      95                 :             :  *  per-peer memory usage spent on announcements, while covering peers continuously sending INVs at the maximum
      96                 :             :  *  rate (by our own policy, see INVENTORY_BROADCAST_PER_SECOND) for several minutes, while not receiving
      97                 :             :  *  the actual transaction (from any peer) in response to requests for them. */
      98                 :             : static constexpr int32_t MAX_PEER_TX_ANNOUNCEMENTS = 5000;

     100                 :             : static constexpr auto TXID_RELAY_DELAY{2s};
     101                 :             : /** How long to delay requesting transactions from non-preferred peers */
     102                 :             : static constexpr auto NONPREF_PEER_TX_DELAY{2s};

     106                 :             : static constexpr auto GETDATA_TX_INTERVAL{60s};

     108                 :             : static const unsigned int MAX_GETDATA_SZ = 1000;

     113                 :             : static constexpr auto BLOCK_STALLING_TIMEOUT_DEFAULT{2s};

     118                 :             : static const int MAX_CMPCTBLOCK_DEPTH = 5;

     121                 :             : static_assert(MAX_BLOCKTXN_DEPTH <= MIN_BLOCKS_TO_KEEP, "MAX_BLOCKTXN_DEPTH too high");
     122                 :             : /** Size of the "block download window": how far ahead of our current height do we fetch?
     123                 :             :  *  Larger windows tolerate larger download speed differences between peer, but increase the potential
     124                 :             :  *  degree of disordering of blocks on disk (which make reindexing and pruning harder). We'll probably
     125                 :             :  *  want to make this a per-peer adaptive value at some point. */
     126                 :             : static const unsigned int BLOCK_DOWNLOAD_WINDOW = 1024;

     191                 :             : /**
     192                 :             :  * Data structure for an individual peer. This struct is not protected by
     193                 :             :  * cs_main since it does not contain validation-critical data.
     194                 :             :  *
     195                 :             :  * Memory is owned by shared pointers and this object is destructed when
     196                 :             :  * the refcount drops to zero.
     197                 :             :  *
     198                 :             :  * Mutexes inside this struct must not be held when locking m_peer_mutex.

     200                 :             :  * TODO: move most members from CNodeState to this structure.

     207                 :             :     /** Services we offered to this peer.
     208                 :             :      *
     209                 :             :      *  This is supplied by CConnman during peer initialization. It's const
     210                 :             :      *  because there is no protocol defined for renegotiating services
     211                 :             :      *  initially offered to a peer. The set of local services we offer should
     212                 :             :      *  not change after initialization.
     213                 :             :      *
     214                 :             :      *  An interesting example of this is NODE_NETWORK and initial block
     215                 :             :      *  download: a node which starts up from scratch doesn't have any blocks
     216                 :             :      *  to serve, but still advertises NODE_NETWORK because it will eventually
     217                 :             :      *  fulfill this role after IBD completes. P2P code is written in such a
     218                 :             :      *  way that it can gracefully handle peers who don't make good on their
     219                 :             :      *  service advertisements. */
     220                 :             :     const ServiceFlags m_our_services;

     317                 :             :     /** A vector of addresses to send to the peer, limited to MAX_ADDR_TO_SEND. */
     318                 :             :     std::vector<CAddress> m_addrs_to_send GUARDED_BY(NetEventsInterface::g_msgproc_mutex);
     319                 :             :     /** Probabilistic filter to track recent addr messages relayed with this
     320                 :             :      *  peer. Used to avoid relaying redundant addresses to this peer.
     321                 :             :      *
     322                 :             :      *  We initialize this filter for outbound peers (other than
     323                 :             :      *  block-relay-only connections) or when an inbound peer sends us an
     324                 :             :      *  address related message (ADDR, ADDRV2, GETADDR).
     325                 :             :      *
     326                 :             :      *  Presence of this filter must correlate with m_addr_relay_enabled.
     327                 :             :      **/
     328                 :             :     std::unique_ptr<CRollingBloomFilter> m_addr_known GUARDED_BY(NetEventsInterface::g_msgproc_mutex);
     329                 :             :     /** Whether we are participating in address relay with this connection.
     330                 :             :      *
     331                 :             :      *  We set this bool to true for outbound peers (other than
     332                 :             :      *  block-relay-only connections), or when an inbound peer sends us an
     333                 :             :      *  address related message (ADDR, ADDRV2, GETADDR).
     334                 :             :      *
     335                 :             :      *  We use this bool to decide whether a peer is eligible for gossiping
     336                 :             :      *  addr messages. This avoids relaying to peers that are unlikely to
     337                 :             :      *  forward them, effectively blackholing self announcements. Reasons
     338                 :             :      *  peers might support addr relay on the link include that they connected
     339                 :             :      *  to us as a block-relay-only peer or they are a light client.
     340                 :             :      *
     341                 :             :      *  This field must correlate with whether m_addr_known has been
     342                 :             :      *  initialized.*/
     343                 :             :     std::atomic_bool m_addr_relay_enabled{false};
     344                 :             :     /** Whether a getaddr request to this peer is outstanding. */
     345                 :             :     bool m_getaddr_sent GUARDED_BY(NetEventsInterface::g_msgproc_mutex){false};

     347                 :             :     mutable Mutex m_addr_send_times_mutex;

     349                 :             :     std::chrono::microseconds m_next_addr_send GUARDED_BY(m_addr_send_times_mutex){0};
     350                 :             :     /** Time point to possibly re-announce our local address to this peer. */
     351                 :             :     std::chrono::microseconds m_next_local_addr_send GUARDED_BY(m_addr_send_times_mutex){0};
     352                 :             :     /** Whether the peer has signaled support for receiving ADDRv2 (BIP155)
     353                 :             :      *  messages, indicating a preference to receive ADDRv2 instead of ADDR ones. */
     354                 :             :     std::atomic_bool m_wants_addrv2{false};
     355                 :             :     /** Whether this peer has already sent us a getaddr message. */

     358                 :             :      *  permit self-announcement. */

     365                 :             :     std::atomic<uint64_t> m_addr_processed{0};

     410                 :             : using PeerRef = std::shared_ptr<Peer>;
     411                 :             : 
     412                 :             : /**
     413                 :             :  * Maintain validation-specific state about nodes, protected by cs_main, instead
     414                 :             :  * by CNode's own locks. This simplifies asynchronous operation, where
     415                 :             :  * processing of incoming data is done after the ProcessMessage call returns,
     416                 :             :  * and we're no longer holding the node's locks.
     417                 :             :  */
     418                 :          26 : struct CNodeState {
     419                 :             :     //! The best known block we know this peer has announced.
     420                 :             :     const CBlockIndex* pindexBestKnownBlock{nullptr};
     421                 :             :     //! The hash of the last unknown block this peer has announced.
     422                 :             :     uint256 hashLastUnknownBlock{};

     424                 :             :     const CBlockIndex* pindexLastCommonBlock{nullptr};

     426                 :             :     const CBlockIndex* pindexBestHeaderSent{nullptr};

     428                 :             :     bool fSyncStarted{false};
     429                 :             :     //! Since when we're stalling block download progress (in microseconds), or 0.
     430                 :             :     std::chrono::microseconds m_stalling_since{0us};
     431                 :             :     std::list<QueuedBlock> vBlocksInFlight;
     432                 :             :     //! When the first entry in vBlocksInFlight started downloading. Don't care when vBlocksInFlight is empty.
     433                 :             :     std::chrono::microseconds m_downloading_since{0us};

     435                 :             :     bool fPreferredDownload{false};
     436                 :             :     /** Whether this peer wants invs or cmpctblocks (when possible) for block announcements. */
     437                 :             :     bool m_requested_hb_cmpctblocks{false};
     438                 :             :     /** Whether this peer will send us cmpctblocks if we request them. */
     439                 :             :     bool m_provides_cmpctblocks{false};
     440                 :             : 
     441                 :             :     /** State used to enforce CHAIN_SYNC_TIMEOUT and EXTRA_PEER_CHECK_INTERVAL logic.
     442                 :             :       *
     443                 :             :       * Both are only in effect for outbound, non-manual, non-protected connections.
     444                 :             :       * Any peer protected (m_protect = true) is not chosen for eviction. A peer is
     445                 :             :       * marked as protected if all of these are true:
     446                 :             :       *   - its connection type is IsBlockOnlyConn() == false
     447                 :             :       *   - it gave us a valid connecting header
     448                 :             :       *   - we haven't reached MAX_OUTBOUND_PEERS_TO_PROTECT_FROM_DISCONNECT yet
     449                 :             :       *   - its chain tip has at least as much work as ours
     450                 :             :       *
     451                 :             :       * CHAIN_SYNC_TIMEOUT: if a peer's best known block has less work than our tip,
     452                 :             :       * set a timeout CHAIN_SYNC_TIMEOUT in the future:
     453                 :             :       *   - If at timeout their best known block now has more work than our tip
     454                 :             :       *     when the timeout was set, then either reset the timeout or clear it
     455                 :             :       *     (after comparing against our current tip's work)
     456                 :             :       *   - If at timeout their best known block still has less work than our
     457                 :             :       *     tip did when the timeout was set, then send a getheaders message,
     458                 :             :       *     and set a shorter timeout, HEADERS_RESPONSE_TIME seconds in future.
     459                 :             :       *     If their best known block is still behind when that new timeout is
     460                 :             :       *     reached, disconnect.
     461                 :             :       *
     462                 :             :       * EXTRA_PEER_CHECK_INTERVAL: after each interval, if we have too many outbound peers,
     463                 :             :       * drop the outbound one that least recently announced us a new block.
     464                 :             :       */
     465                 :             :     struct ChainSyncTimeoutState {
     466                 :             :         //! A timeout used for checking whether our peer has sufficiently synced
     467                 :             :         std::chrono::seconds m_timeout{0s};
     468                 :             :         //! A header with the work we require on our peer's chain
     469                 :             :         const CBlockIndex* m_work_header{nullptr};
     470                 :             :         //! After timeout is reached, set to true after sending getheaders
     471                 :             :         bool m_sent_getheaders{false};
     472                 :             :         //! Whether this peer is protected from disconnection due to a bad/slow chain
     473                 :             :         bool m_protect{false};
     474                 :             :     };
     475                 :             : 
     476                 :             :     ChainSyncTimeoutState m_chain_sync;
     477                 :             : 
     478                 :             :     //! Time of last new block announcement
     479                 :             :     int64_t m_last_block_announcement{0};
     480                 :             : };

     632                 :             :     /**
     633                 :             :      * Reconsider orphan transactions after a parent has been accepted to the mempool.
     634                 :             :      *
     635                 :             :      * @peer[in]  peer     The peer whose orphan transactions we will reconsider. Generally only
     636                 :             :      *                     one orphan will be reconsidered on each call of this function. If an
     637                 :             :      *                     accepted orphan has orphaned children, those will need to be
     638                 :             :      *                     reconsidered, creating more work, possibly for other peers.
     639                 :             :      * @return             True if meaningful work was done (an orphan was accepted/rejected).
     640                 :             :      *                     If no meaningful work was done, then the work set for this peer
     641                 :             :      *                     will be empty.
     642                 :             :      */
     643                 :             :     bool ProcessOrphanTx(Peer& peer)
     644                 :             :         EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(!m_peer_mutex, g_msgproc_mutex, !m_tx_download_mutex);
     645                 :             : 
     646                 :             :     /** Process a single headers message from a peer.
     647                 :             :      *
     648                 :             :      * @param[in]   pfrom     CNode of the peer
     649                 :             :      * @param[in]   peer      The peer sending us the headers
     650                 :             :      * @param[in]   headers   The headers received. Note that this may be modified within ProcessHeadersMessage.
     651                 :             :      * @param[in]   via_compact_block   Whether this header came in via compact block handling.
     652                 :             :     */
     653                 :             :     void ProcessHeadersMessage(CNode& pfrom, Peer& peer,
     654                 :             :                                std::vector<CBlockHeader>&& headers,
     655                 :             :                                bool via_compact_block)
     656                 :             :         EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(!m_peer_mutex, !m_headers_presync_mutex, g_msgproc_mutex);
     657                 :             :     /** Various helpers for headers processing, invoked by ProcessHeadersMessage() */
     658                 :             :     /** Return true if headers are continuous and have valid proof-of-work (DoS points assigned on failure) */
     659                 :             :     bool CheckHeadersPoW(const std::vector<CBlockHeader>& headers, const Consensus::Params& consensusParams, Peer& peer);
     660                 :             :     /** Calculate an anti-DoS work threshold for headers chains */
     661                 :             :     arith_uint256 GetAntiDoSWorkThreshold();
     662                 :             :     /** Deal with state tracking and headers sync for peers that send
     663                 :             :      * non-connecting headers (this can happen due to BIP 130 headers
     664                 :             :      * announcements for blocks interacting with the 2hr (MAX_FUTURE_BLOCK_TIME) rule). */
     665                 :             :     void HandleUnconnectingHeaders(CNode& pfrom, Peer& peer, const std::vector<CBlockHeader>& headers) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(g_msgproc_mutex);
     666                 :             :     /** Return true if the headers connect to each other, false otherwise */
     667                 :             :     bool CheckHeadersAreContinuous(const std::vector<CBlockHeader>& headers) const;
     668                 :             :     /** Try to continue a low-work headers sync that has already begun.
     669                 :             :      * Assumes the caller has already verified the headers connect, and has
     670                 :             :      * checked that each header satisfies the proof-of-work target included in
     671                 :             :      * the header.
     672                 :             :      *  @param[in]  peer                            The peer we're syncing with.
     673                 :             :      *  @param[in]  pfrom                           CNode of the peer
     674                 :             :      *  @param[in,out] headers                      The headers to be processed.
     675                 :             :      *  @return     True if the passed in headers were successfully processed
     676                 :             :      *              as the continuation of a low-work headers sync in progress;
     677                 :             :      *              false otherwise.
     678                 :             :      *              If false, the passed in headers will be returned back to
     679                 :             :      *              the caller.
     680                 :             :      *              If true, the returned headers may be empty, indicating
     681                 :             :      *              there is no more work for the caller to do; or the headers
     682                 :             :      *              may be populated with entries that have passed anti-DoS
     683                 :             :      *              checks (and therefore may be validated for block index
     684                 :             :      *              acceptance by the caller).
     685                 :             :      */
     686                 :             :     bool IsContinuationOfLowWorkHeadersSync(Peer& peer, CNode& pfrom,
     687                 :             :             std::vector<CBlockHeader>& headers)
     688                 :             :         EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(peer.m_headers_sync_mutex, !m_headers_presync_mutex, g_msgproc_mutex);
     689                 :             :     /** Check work on a headers chain to be processed, and if insufficient,
     690                 :             :      * initiate our anti-DoS headers sync mechanism.
     691                 :             :      *
     692                 :             :      * @param[in]   peer                The peer whose headers we're processing.
     693                 :             :      * @param[in]   pfrom               CNode of the peer
     694                 :             :      * @param[in]   chain_start_header  Where these headers connect in our index.
     695                 :             :      * @param[in,out]   headers             The headers to be processed.
     696                 :             :      *
     697                 :             :      * @return      True if chain was low work (headers will be empty after
     698                 :             :      *              calling); false otherwise.
     699                 :             :      */
     700                 :             :     bool TryLowWorkHeadersSync(Peer& peer, CNode& pfrom,
     701                 :             :                                   const CBlockIndex* chain_start_header,
     702                 :             :                                   std::vector<CBlockHeader>& headers)

     774                 :             : 
     775                 :             :     /** Synchronizes tx download including TxRequestTracker, rejection filters, and TxOrphanage.
     776                 :             :      * Lock invariants:
     777                 :             :      * - A txhash (txid or wtxid) in m_txrequest is not also in m_orphanage.
     778                 :             :      * - A txhash (txid or wtxid) in m_txrequest is not also in m_lazy_recent_rejects.
     779                 :             :      * - A txhash (txid or wtxid) in m_txrequest is not also in m_lazy_recent_rejects_reconsiderable.
     780                 :             :      * - A txhash (txid or wtxid) in m_txrequest is not also in m_lazy_recent_confirmed_transactions.
     781                 :             :      * - Each data structure's limits hold (m_orphanage max size, m_txrequest per-peer limits, etc).
     782                 :             :      */
     783                 :             :     Mutex m_tx_download_mutex ACQUIRED_BEFORE(m_mempool.cs);

     806                 :             :     /** Protects m_peer_map. This mutex must not be locked while holding a lock

     808                 :             :     mutable Mutex m_peer_mutex;

     842                 :             : 
     843                 :             :     /** Number of peers with wtxid relay. */
     844                 :             :     std::atomic<int> m_wtxid_relay_peers{0};
     845                 :             :

     847                 :             :     int m_outbound_peers_with_protect_from_disconnect GUARDED_BY(cs_main) = 0;
     848                 :             : 
     849                 :             :     /** Number of preferable block download peers. */
     850                 :             :     int m_num_preferred_download_peers GUARDED_BY(cs_main){0};
     851                 :             : 
     852                 :             :     /** Stalling timeout for blocks in IBD */
     853                 :             :     std::atomic<std::chrono::seconds> m_block_stalling_timeout{BLOCK_STALLING_TIMEOUT_DEFAULT};
     854                 :             : 
     855                 :             :     /** Check whether we already have this gtxid in:
     856                 :             :      *  - mempool
     857                 :             :      *  - orphanage
     858                 :             :      *  - m_lazy_recent_rejects
     859                 :             :      *  - m_lazy_recent_rejects_reconsiderable (if include_reconsiderable = true)
     860                 :             :      *  - m_lazy_recent_confirmed_transactions
     861                 :             :      *  */
     862                 :             :     bool AlreadyHaveTx(const GenTxid& gtxid, bool include_reconsiderable)
     863                 :             :         EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(m_tx_download_mutex);
     864                 :             : 
     865                 :             :     /**
     866                 :             :      * Filter for transactions that were recently rejected by the mempool.
     867                 :             :      * These are not rerequested until the chain tip changes, at which point
     868                 :             :      * the entire filter is reset.
     869                 :             :      *
     870                 :             :      * Without this filter we'd be re-requesting txs from each of our peers,
     871                 :             :      * increasing bandwidth consumption considerably. For instance, with 100
     872                 :             :      * peers, half of which relay a tx we don't accept, that might be a 50x
     873                 :             :      * bandwidth increase. A flooding attacker attempting to roll-over the
     874                 :             :      * filter using minimum-sized, 60byte, transactions might manage to send
     875                 :             :      * 1000/sec if we have fast peers, so we pick 120,000 to give our peers a
     876                 :             :      * two minute window to send invs to us.
     877                 :             :      *
     878                 :             :      * Decreasing the false positive rate is fairly cheap, so we pick one in a
     879                 :             :      * million to make it highly unlikely for users to have issues with this
     880                 :             :      * filter.
     881                 :             :      *
     882                 :             :      * We typically only add wtxids to this filter. For non-segwit
     883                 :             :      * transactions, the txid == wtxid, so this only prevents us from
     884                 :             :      * re-downloading non-segwit transactions when communicating with
     885                 :             :      * non-wtxidrelay peers -- which is important for avoiding malleation
     886                 :             :      * attacks that could otherwise interfere with transaction relay from
     887                 :             :      * non-wtxidrelay peers. For communicating with wtxidrelay peers, having
     888                 :             :      * the reject filter store wtxids is exactly what we want to avoid
     889                 :             :      * redownload of a rejected transaction.
     890                 :             :      *
     891                 :             :      * In cases where we can tell that a segwit transaction will fail
     892                 :             :      * validation no matter the witness, we may add the txid of such
     893                 :             :      * transaction to the filter as well. This can be helpful when
     894                 :             :      * communicating with txid-relay peers or if we were to otherwise fetch a
     895                 :             :      * transaction via txid (eg in our orphan handling).
     896                 :             :      *
     897                 :             :      * Memory used: 1.3 MB
     898                 :             :      */
     899                 :             :     std::unique_ptr<CRollingBloomFilter> m_lazy_recent_rejects GUARDED_BY(m_tx_download_mutex){nullptr};
     900                 :             : 
     901                 :           1 :     CRollingBloomFilter& RecentRejectsFilter() EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(m_tx_download_mutex)
     902                 :             :     {
     903                 :           1 :         AssertLockHeld(m_tx_download_mutex);
     904                 :             : 
     905         [ +  - ]:           1 :         if (!m_lazy_recent_rejects) {
     906                 :           1 :             m_lazy_recent_rejects = std::make_unique<CRollingBloomFilter>(120'000, 0.000'001);
     907                 :             :         }
     908                 :             : 
     909                 :           1 :         return *m_lazy_recent_rejects;
     910                 :             :     }
     911                 :             : 
     912                 :             :     /**
     913                 :             :      * Filter for:
     914                 :             :      * (1) wtxids of transactions that were recently rejected by the mempool but are
     915                 :             :      * eligible for reconsideration if submitted with other transactions.
     916                 :             :      * (2) packages (see GetPackageHash) we have already rejected before and should not retry.
     917                 :             :      *
     918                 :             :      * Similar to m_lazy_recent_rejects, this filter is used to save bandwidth when e.g. all of our peers
     919                 :             :      * have larger mempools and thus lower minimum feerates than us.
     920                 :             :      *
     921                 :             :      * When a transaction's error is TxValidationResult::TX_RECONSIDERABLE (in a package or by
     922                 :             :      * itself), add its wtxid to this filter. When a package fails for any reason, add the combined
     923                 :             :      * hash to this filter.
     924                 :             :      *
     925                 :             :      * Upon receiving an announcement for a transaction, if it exists in this filter, do not
     926                 :             :      * download the txdata. When considering packages, if it exists in this filter, drop it.
     927                 :             :      *
     928                 :             :      * Reset this filter when the chain tip changes.
     929                 :             :      *
     930                 :             :      * Parameters are picked to be the same as m_lazy_recent_rejects, with the same rationale.
     931                 :             :      */
     932                 :             :     std::unique_ptr<CRollingBloomFilter> m_lazy_recent_rejects_reconsiderable GUARDED_BY(m_tx_download_mutex){nullptr};
     933                 :             : 
     934                 :           1 :     CRollingBloomFilter& RecentRejectsReconsiderableFilter() EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(m_tx_download_mutex)
     935                 :             :     {
     936                 :           1 :         AssertLockHeld(m_tx_download_mutex);
     937                 :             : 
     938         [ +  - ]:           1 :         if (!m_lazy_recent_rejects_reconsiderable) {
     939                 :           1 :             m_lazy_recent_rejects_reconsiderable = std::make_unique<CRollingBloomFilter>(120'000, 0.000'001);
     940                 :             :         }
     941                 :             : 
     942                 :           1 :         return *m_lazy_recent_rejects_reconsiderable;
     943                 :             :     }
     944                 :             : 
     945                 :             :     /*
     946                 :             :      * Filter for transactions that have been recently confirmed.
     947                 :             :      * We use this to avoid requesting transactions that have already been
     948                 :             :      * confirnmed.
     949                 :             :      *
     950                 :             :      * Blocks don't typically have more than 4000 transactions, so this should
     951                 :             :      * be at least six blocks (~1 hr) worth of transactions that we can store,
     952                 :             :      * inserting both a txid and wtxid for every observed transaction.
     953                 :             :      * If the number of transactions appearing in a block goes up, or if we are
     954                 :             :      * seeing getdata requests more than an hour after initial announcement, we
     955                 :             :      * can increase this number.
     956                 :             :      * The false positive rate of 1/1M should come out to less than 1
     957                 :             :      * transaction per day that would be inadvertently ignored (which is the
     958                 :             :      * same probability that we have in the reject filter).
     959                 :             :      */
     960                 :             :     std::unique_ptr<CRollingBloomFilter> m_lazy_recent_confirmed_transactions GUARDED_BY(m_tx_download_mutex){nullptr};
     961                 :             : 
     962                 :           4 :     CRollingBloomFilter& RecentConfirmedTransactionsFilter() EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(m_tx_download_mutex)
     963                 :             :     {
     964                 :           4 :         AssertLockHeld(m_tx_download_mutex);
     965                 :             : 
     966         [ +  + ]:           4 :         if (!m_lazy_recent_confirmed_transactions) {
     967                 :           1 :             m_lazy_recent_confirmed_transactions = std::make_unique<CRollingBloomFilter>(48'000, 0.000'001);
     968                 :             :         }
     969                 :             : 
     970                 :           4 :         return *m_lazy_recent_confirmed_transactions;
     971                 :             :     }
     972                 :             : 
     973                 :             :     /**
     974                 :             :      * For sending `inv`s to inbound peers, we use a single (exponentially
     975                 :             :      * distributed) timer for all peers. If we used a separate timer for each
     976                 :             :      * peer, a spy node could make multiple inbound connections to us to
     977                 :             :      * accurately determine when we received the transaction (and potentially
     978                 :             :      * determine the transaction's origin). */
     979                 :             :     std::chrono::microseconds NextInvToInbounds(std::chrono::microseconds now,
     980                 :             :                                                 std::chrono::seconds average_interval) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(g_msgproc_mutex);
     981                 :             : 
     982                 :             : 
     983                 :             :     // All of the following cache a recent block, and are protected by m_most_recent_block_mutex
     984                 :             :     Mutex m_most_recent_block_mutex;
     985                 :             :     std::shared_ptr<const CBlock> m_most_recent_block GUARDED_BY(m_most_recent_block_mutex);
     986                 :             :     std::shared_ptr<const CBlockHeaderAndShortTxIDs> m_most_recent_compact_block GUARDED_BY(m_most_recent_block_mutex);
     987                 :             :     uint256 m_most_recent_block_hash GUARDED_BY(m_most_recent_block_mutex);
     988                 :             :     std::unique_ptr<const std::map<uint256, CTransactionRef>> m_most_recent_block_txs GUARDED_BY(m_most_recent_block_mutex);
     989                 :             : 
     990                 :             :     // Data about the low-work headers synchronization, aggregated from all peers' HeadersSyncStates.
     991                 :             :     /** Mutex guarding the other m_headers_presync_* variables. */
     992                 :             :     Mutex m_headers_presync_mutex;
     993                 :             :     /** A type to represent statistics about a peer's low-work headers sync.
     994                 :             :      *
     995                 :             :      * - The first field is the total verified amount of work in that synchronization.
     996                 :             :      * - The second is:
     997                 :             :      *   - nullopt: the sync is in REDOWNLOAD phase (phase 2).
     998                 :             :      *   - {height, timestamp}: the sync has the specified tip height and block timestamp (phase 1).
     999                 :             :      */
    1000                 :             :     using HeadersPresyncStats = std::pair<arith_uint256, std::optional<std::pair<int64_t, uint32_t>>>;
    1001                 :             :     /** Statistics for all peers in low-work headers sync. */
    1002                 :             :     std::map<NodeId, HeadersPresyncStats> m_headers_presync_stats GUARDED_BY(m_headers_presync_mutex) {};
    1003                 :             :     /** The peer with the most-work entry in m_headers_presync_stats. */
    1004                 :             :     NodeId m_headers_presync_bestpeer GUARDED_BY(m_headers_presync_mutex) {-1};
    1005                 :             :     /** The m_headers_presync_stats improved, and needs signalling. */
    1006                 :             :     std::atomic_bool m_headers_presync_should_signal{false};
    1007                 :             : 
    1008                 :             :     /** Height of the highest block announced using BIP 152 high-bandwidth mode. */
    1009                 :             :     int m_highest_fast_announce GUARDED_BY(::cs_main){0};
    1010                 :             : 
    1011                 :             :     /** Have we requested this block from a peer */
    1012                 :             :     bool IsBlockRequested(const uint256& hash) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
    1013                 :             : 
    1014                 :             :     /** Have we requested this block from an outbound peer */
    1015                 :             :     bool IsBlockRequestedFromOutbound(const uint256& hash) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main, !m_peer_mutex);
    1016                 :             : 
    1017                 :             :     /** Remove this block from our tracked requested blocks. Called if:
    1018                 :             :      *  - the block has been received from a peer
    1019                 :             :      *  - the request for the block has timed out
    1020                 :             :      * If "from_peer" is specified, then only remove the block if it is in
    1021                 :             :      * flight from that peer (to avoid one peer's network traffic from
    1022                 :             :      * affecting another's state).
    1023                 :             :      */
    1024                 :             :     void RemoveBlockRequest(const uint256& hash, std::optional<NodeId> from_peer) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
    1025                 :             : 
    1026                 :             :     /* Mark a block as in flight
    1027                 :             :      * Returns false, still setting pit, if the block was already in flight from the same peer
    1028                 :             :      * pit will only be valid as long as the same cs_main lock is being held
    1029                 :             :      */
    1030                 :             :     bool BlockRequested(NodeId nodeid, const CBlockIndex& block, std::list<QueuedBlock>::iterator** pit = nullptr) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
    1031                 :             : 
    1032                 :             :     bool TipMayBeStale() EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
    1033                 :             : 
    1034                 :             :     /** Update pindexLastCommonBlock and add not-in-flight missing successors to vBlocks, until it has
    1035                 :             :      *  at most count entries.
    1036                 :             :      */
    1037                 :             :     void FindNextBlocksToDownload(const Peer& peer, unsigned int count, std::vector<const CBlockIndex*>& vBlocks, NodeId& nodeStaller) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
    1038                 :             : 
    1039                 :             :     /** Request blocks for the background chainstate, if one is in use. */
    1040                 :             :     void TryDownloadingHistoricalBlocks(const Peer& peer, unsigned int count, std::vector<const CBlockIndex*>& vBlocks, const CBlockIndex* from_tip, const CBlockIndex* target_block) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
    1041                 :             : 
    1042                 :             :     /**
    1043                 :             :     * \brief Find next blocks to download from a peer after a starting block.
    1044                 :             :     *
    1045                 :             :     * \param vBlocks      Vector of blocks to download which will be appended to.
    1046                 :             :     * \param peer         Peer which blocks will be downloaded from.
    1047                 :             :     * \param state        Pointer to the state of the peer.
    1048                 :             :     * \param pindexWalk   Pointer to the starting block to add to vBlocks.
    1049                 :             :     * \param count        Maximum number of blocks to allow in vBlocks. No more
    1050                 :             :     *                     blocks will be added if it reaches this size.
    1051                 :             :     * \param nWindowEnd   Maximum height of blocks to allow in vBlocks. No
    1052                 :             :     *                     blocks will be added above this height.
    1053                 :             :     * \param activeChain  Optional pointer to a chain to compare against. If
    1054                 :             :     *                     provided, any next blocks which are already contained
    1055                 :             :     *                     in this chain will not be appended to vBlocks, but
    1056                 :             :     *                     instead will be used to update the
    1057                 :             :     *                     state->pindexLastCommonBlock pointer.
    1058                 :             :     * \param nodeStaller  Optional pointer to a NodeId variable that will receive
    1059                 :             :     *                     the ID of another peer that might be causing this peer
    1060                 :             :     *                     to stall. This is set to the ID of the peer which
    1061                 :             :     *                     first requested the first in-flight block in the
    1062                 :             :     *                     download window. It is only set if vBlocks is empty at
    1063                 :             :     *                     the end of this function call and if increasing
    1064                 :             :     *                     nWindowEnd by 1 would cause it to be non-empty (which
    1065                 :             :     *                     indicates the download might be stalled because every
    1066                 :             :     *                     block in the window is in flight and no other peer is
    1067                 :             :     *                     trying to download the next block).
    1068                 :             :     */
    1069                 :             :     void FindNextBlocks(std::vector<const CBlockIndex*>& vBlocks, const Peer& peer, CNodeState *state, const CBlockIndex *pindexWalk, unsigned int count, int nWindowEnd, const CChain* activeChain=nullptr, NodeId* nodeStaller=nullptr) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);

    1382                 :           0 : void PeerManagerImpl::MaybeSetPeerAsAnnouncingHeaderAndIDs(NodeId nodeid)
    1383                 :             : {
    1384                 :           0 :     AssertLockHeld(cs_main);
    1385                 :             : 
    1386                 :             :     // When in -blocksonly mode, never request high-bandwidth mode from peers. Our
    1387                 :             :     // mempool will not contain the transactions necessary to reconstruct the
    1388                 :             :     // compact block.
    1389         [ #  # ]:           0 :     if (m_opts.ignore_incoming_txs) return;
    1390                 :             : 
    1391                 :           0 :     CNodeState* nodestate = State(nodeid);
    1392                 :           0 :     PeerRef peer{GetPeerRef(nodeid)};
    1393   [ #  #  #  # ]:           0 :     if (!nodestate || !nodestate->m_provides_cmpctblocks) {
    1394                 :             :         // Don't request compact blocks if the peer has not signalled support
    1395                 :             :         return;
    1396                 :             :     }
    1397                 :             : 
    1398                 :           0 :     int num_outbound_hb_peers = 0;
    1399         [ #  # ]:           0 :     for (std::list<NodeId>::iterator it = lNodesAnnouncingHeaderAndIDs.begin(); it != lNodesAnnouncingHeaderAndIDs.end(); it++) {
    1400         [ #  # ]:           0 :         if (*it == nodeid) {
    1401                 :           0 :             lNodesAnnouncingHeaderAndIDs.erase(it);
    1402         [ #  # ]:           0 :             lNodesAnnouncingHeaderAndIDs.push_back(nodeid);
    1403                 :             :             return;
    1404                 :             :         }
    1405         [ #  # ]:           0 :         PeerRef peer_ref{GetPeerRef(*it)};
    1406   [ #  #  #  # ]:           0 :         if (peer_ref && !peer_ref->m_is_inbound) ++num_outbound_hb_peers;
    1407                 :           0 :     }
    1408   [ #  #  #  # ]:           0 :     if (peer && peer->m_is_inbound) {
    1409                 :             :         // If we're adding an inbound HB peer, make sure we're not removing
    1410                 :             :         // our last outbound HB peer in the process.
    1411   [ #  #  #  # ]:           0 :         if (lNodesAnnouncingHeaderAndIDs.size() >= 3 && num_outbound_hb_peers == 1) {

    1413   [ #  #  #  # ]:           0 :             if (remove_peer && !remove_peer->m_is_inbound) {
    1414                 :             :                 // Put the HB outbound peer in the second slot, so that it
    1415                 :             :                 // doesn't get removed.
    1416                 :           0 :                 std::swap(lNodesAnnouncingHeaderAndIDs.front(), *std::next(lNodesAnnouncingHeaderAndIDs.begin()));

    1582                 :           0 : void PeerManagerImpl::FindNextBlocks(std::vector<const CBlockIndex*>& vBlocks, const Peer& peer, CNodeState *state, const CBlockIndex *pindexWalk, unsigned int count, int nWindowEnd, const CChain* activeChain, NodeId* nodeStaller)

    1584                 :           0 :     std::vector<const CBlockIndex*> vToFetch;
    1585         [ #  # ]:           0 :     int nMaxHeight = std::min<int>(state->pindexBestKnownBlock->nHeight, nWindowEnd + 1);
    1586                 :           0 :     bool is_limited_peer = IsLimitedPeer(peer);
    1587                 :           0 :     NodeId waitingfor = -1;
    1588         [ #  # ]:           0 :     while (pindexWalk->nHeight < nMaxHeight) {
    1589                 :             :         // Read up to 128 (or more, if more blocks than that are needed) successors of pindexWalk (towards
    1590                 :             :         // pindexBestKnownBlock) into vToFetch. We fetch 128, because CBlockIndex::GetAncestor may be as expensive
    1591                 :             :         // as iterating over ~100 CBlockIndex* entries anyway.

    1593         [ #  # ]:           0 :         vToFetch.resize(nToFetch);
    1594         [ #  # ]:           0 :         pindexWalk = state->pindexBestKnownBlock->GetAncestor(pindexWalk->nHeight + nToFetch);
    1595                 :           0 :         vToFetch[nToFetch - 1] = pindexWalk;

    1597                 :           0 :             vToFetch[i - 1] = vToFetch[i]->pprev;
    1598                 :             :         }
    1599                 :             : 
    1600                 :             :         // Iterate over those blocks in vToFetch (in forward direction), adding the ones that
    1601                 :             :         // are not yet downloaded and not in flight to vBlocks. In the meantime, update
    1602                 :             :         // pindexLastCommonBlock as long as all ancestors are already downloaded, or if it's

    1607                 :             :                 return;
    1608                 :             :             }
    1609                 :             :

    1612                 :             :                 return;

    1681                 :           0 : void PeerManagerImpl::AddTxAnnouncement(const CNode& node, const GenTxid& gtxid, std::chrono::microseconds current_time)
    1682                 :             : {
    1683                 :           0 :     AssertLockHeld(::cs_main); // for State
    1684                 :           0 :     AssertLockHeld(m_tx_download_mutex); // For m_txrequest
    1685         [ #  # ]:           0 :     NodeId nodeid = node.GetId();
    1686   [ #  #  #  # ]:           0 :     if (!node.HasPermission(NetPermissionFlags::Relay) && m_txrequest.Count(nodeid) >= MAX_PEER_TX_ANNOUNCEMENTS) {
    1687                 :             :         // Too many queued announcements from this peer
    1688                 :             :         return;
    1689                 :             :     }
    1690                 :           0 :     const CNodeState* state = State(nodeid);
    1691                 :             : 
    1692                 :             :     // Decide the TxRequestTracker parameters for this announcement:
    1693                 :             :     // - "preferred": if fPreferredDownload is set (= outbound, or NetPermissionFlags::NoBan permission)
    1694                 :             :     // - "reqtime": current time plus delays for:
    1695                 :             :     //   - NONPREF_PEER_TX_DELAY for announcements from non-preferred connections
    1696                 :             :     //   - TXID_RELAY_DELAY for txid announcements while wtxid peers are available
    1697                 :             :     //   - OVERLOADED_PEER_TX_DELAY for announcements from peers which have at least
    1698                 :             :     //     MAX_PEER_TX_REQUEST_IN_FLIGHT requests in flight (and don't have NetPermissionFlags::Relay).
    1699                 :           0 :     auto delay{0us};
    1700                 :           0 :     const bool preferred = state->fPreferredDownload;
    1701         [ #  # ]:           0 :     if (!preferred) delay += NONPREF_PEER_TX_DELAY;
    1702   [ #  #  #  # ]:           0 :     if (!gtxid.IsWtxid() && m_wtxid_relay_peers > 0) delay += TXID_RELAY_DELAY;
    1703   [ #  #  #  # ]:           0 :     const bool overloaded = !node.HasPermission(NetPermissionFlags::Relay) &&
    1704                 :           0 :         m_txrequest.CountInFlight(nodeid) >= MAX_PEER_TX_REQUEST_IN_FLIGHT;
    1705                 :           0 :     if (overloaded) delay += OVERLOADED_PEER_TX_DELAY;
    1706                 :           0 :     m_txrequest.ReceivedInv(nodeid, gtxid, preferred, current_time + delay);
    1707                 :             : }

    1739                 :           0 : void PeerManagerImpl::ReattemptInitialBroadcast(CScheduler& scheduler)
    1740                 :             : {
    1741                 :           0 :     std::set<uint256> unbroadcast_txids = m_mempool.GetUnbroadcastTxs();
    1742                 :             : 
    1743         [ #  # ]:           0 :     for (const auto& txid : unbroadcast_txids) {
    1744         [ #  # ]:           0 :         CTransactionRef tx = m_mempool.get(txid);
    1745                 :             : 
    1746         [ #  # ]:           0 :         if (tx != nullptr) {
    1747         [ #  # ]:           0 :             RelayTransaction(txid, tx->GetWitnessHash());
    1748                 :             :         } else {
    1749         [ #  # ]:           0 :             m_mempool.RemoveUnbroadcastTx(txid, true);
    1750                 :             :         }
    1751                 :           0 :     }
    1752                 :             : 
    1753                 :             :     // Schedule next run for 10-15 minutes in the future.
    1754                 :             :     // We add randomness on every cycle to avoid the possibility of P2P fingerprinting.
    1755                 :           0 :     const auto delta = 10min + FastRandomContext().randrange<std::chrono::milliseconds>(5min);

    1887                 :             :     // It is common for nodes with good ping times to suddenly become lagged,
    1888                 :             :     // due to a new block arriving or other large transfer.
    1889                 :             :     // Merely reporting pingtime might fool the caller into thinking the node was still responsive,
    1890                 :             :     // since pingtime does not update until the ping is complete, which might take a while.
    1891                 :             :     // So, if a ping is taking an unusually long time in flight,
    1892                 :             :     // the caller can immediately detect that this is happening.

    2101                 :           0 : void PeerManagerImpl::StartScheduledTasks(CScheduler& scheduler)
    2102                 :             : {
    2103                 :             :     // Stale tip checking and peer eviction are on two different timers, but we
    2104                 :             :     // don't want them to get out of sync due to drift in the scheduler, so we
    2105                 :             :     // combine them in one function and schedule at the quicker (peer-eviction)
    2106                 :             :     // timer.
    2107                 :           0 :     static_assert(EXTRA_PEER_CHECK_INTERVAL < STALE_CHECK_INTERVAL, "peer eviction timer should be less than stale tip check timer");
    2108         [ #  # ]:           0 :     scheduler.scheduleEvery([this] { this->CheckForStaleTipAndEvictPeers(); }, std::chrono::seconds{EXTRA_PEER_CHECK_INTERVAL});
    2109                 :             : 
    2110                 :             :     // schedule next run for 10-15 minutes in the future
    2111                 :           0 :     const auto delta = 10min + FastRandomContext().randrange<std::chrono::milliseconds>(5min);
    2112         [ #  # ]:           0 :     scheduler.scheduleFromNow([&] { ReattemptInitialBroadcast(scheduler); }, delta);
    2113                 :           0 : }
    2114                 :             :

    2175                 :           0 : void PeerManagerImpl::BlockDisconnected(const std::shared_ptr<const CBlock> &block, const CBlockIndex* pindex)
    2176                 :             : {
    2177                 :             :     // To avoid relay problems with transactions that were previously
    2178                 :             :     // confirmed, clear our filter of recently confirmed transactions whenever
    2179                 :             :     // there's a reorg.
    2180                 :             :     // This means that in a 1-block reorg (where 1 block is disconnected and
    2181                 :             :     // then another block reconnected), our filter will drop to having only one
    2182                 :             :     // block's worth of transactions in it, but that should be fine, since
    2183                 :             :     // presumably the most common case of relaying a confirmed transaction
    2184                 :             :     // should be just after a new block containing it is found.

    2323                 :           0 : bool PeerManagerImpl::AlreadyHaveTx(const GenTxid& gtxid, bool include_reconsiderable)
    2324                 :             : {
    2325                 :           0 :     AssertLockHeld(m_tx_download_mutex);
    2326                 :             :

    2328                 :             : 
    2329         [ #  # ]:           0 :     if (gtxid.IsWtxid()) {
    2330                 :             :         // Normal query by wtxid.
    2331         [ #  # ]:           0 :         if (m_orphanage.HaveTx(Wtxid::FromUint256(hash))) return true;
    2332                 :             :     } else {
    2333                 :             :         // Never query by txid: it is possible that the transaction in the orphanage has the same
    2334                 :             :         // txid but a different witness, which would give us a false positive result. If we decided
    2335                 :             :         // not to request the transaction based on this result, an attacker could prevent us from
    2336                 :             :         // downloading a transaction by intentionally creating a malleated version of it.  While
    2337                 :             :         // only one (or none!) of these transactions can ultimately be confirmed, we have no way of
    2338                 :             :         // discerning which one that is, so the orphanage can store multiple transactions with the
    2339                 :             :         // same txid.
    2340                 :             :         //
    2341                 :             :         // While we won't query by txid, we can try to "guess" what the wtxid is based on the txid.
    2342                 :             :         // A non-segwit transaction's txid == wtxid. Query this txid "casted" to a wtxid. This will
    2343                 :             :         // help us find non-segwit transactions, saving bandwidth, and should have no false positives.
    2344         [ #  # ]:           0 :         if (m_orphanage.HaveTx(Wtxid::FromUint256(hash))) return true;
    2345                 :             :     }
    2346                 :             :

    2387                 :             : 
    2388                 :           0 : void PeerManagerImpl::RelayAddress(NodeId originator,
    2389                 :             :                                    const CAddress& addr,
    2390                 :             :                                    bool fReachable)
    2391                 :             : {
    2392                 :             :     // We choose the same nodes within a given 24h window (if the list of connected
    2393                 :             :     // nodes does not change) and we don't relay to nodes that already know an
    2394                 :             :     // address. So within 24h we will likely relay a given address once. This is to
    2395                 :             :     // prevent a peer from unjustly giving their address better propagation by sending
    2396                 :             :     // it to us repeatedly.
    2397                 :             : 
    2398   [ #  #  #  # ]:           0 :     if (!fReachable && !addr.IsRelayable()) return;
    2399                 :             : 
    2400                 :             :     // Relay to a limited number of other nodes
    2401                 :             :     // Use deterministic randomness to send to the same nodes for 24 hours
    2402                 :             :     // at a time so the m_addr_knowns of the chosen nodes prevent repeats
    2403                 :           0 :     const uint64_t hash_addr{CServiceHash(0, 0)(addr)};
    2404                 :           0 :     const auto current_time{GetTime<std::chrono::seconds>()};
    2405                 :             :     // Adding address hash makes exact rotation time different per address, while preserving periodicity.
    2406                 :           0 :     const uint64_t time_addr{(static_cast<uint64_t>(count_seconds(current_time)) + hash_addr) / count_seconds(ROTATE_ADDR_RELAY_DEST_INTERVAL)};
    2407                 :           0 :     const CSipHasher hasher{m_connman.GetDeterministicRandomizer(RANDOMIZER_ID_ADDRESS_RELAY)
    2408                 :           0 :                                 .Write(hash_addr)
    2409                 :           0 :                                 .Write(time_addr)};
    2410                 :             : 
    2411                 :             :     // Relay reachable addresses to 2 peers. Unreachable addresses are relayed randomly to 1 or 2 peers.
    2412   [ #  #  #  # ]:           0 :     unsigned int nRelayNodes = (fReachable || (hasher.Finalize() & 1)) ? 2 : 1;
    2413                 :             : 
    2414                 :           0 :     std::array<std::pair<uint64_t, Peer*>, 2> best{{{0, nullptr}, {0, nullptr}}};
    2415         [ #  # ]:           0 :     assert(nRelayNodes <= best.size());
    2416                 :             : 
    2417                 :           0 :     LOCK(m_peer_mutex);
    2418                 :             : 
    2419   [ #  #  #  # ]:           0 :     for (auto& [id, peer] : m_peer_map) {
    2420   [ #  #  #  #  :           0 :         if (peer->m_addr_relay_enabled && id != originator && IsAddrCompatible(*peer, addr)) {
             #  #  #  # ]
    2421   [ #  #  #  # ]:           0 :             uint64_t hashKey = CSipHasher(hasher).Write(id).Finalize();
    2422         [ #  # ]:           0 :             for (unsigned int i = 0; i < nRelayNodes; i++) {
    2423         [ #  # ]:           0 :                  if (hashKey > best[i].first) {
    2424                 :           0 :                      std::copy(best.begin() + i, best.begin() + nRelayNodes - 1, best.begin() + i + 1);
    2425                 :           0 :                      best[i] = std::make_pair(hashKey, peer.get());
    2426                 :           0 :                      break;
    2427                 :             :                  }
    2428                 :             :             }
    2429                 :             :         }
    2430                 :             :     };
    2431                 :             : 
    2432   [ #  #  #  # ]:           0 :     for (unsigned int i = 0; i < nRelayNodes && best[i].first != 0; i++) {
    2433         [ #  # ]:           0 :         PushAddress(*best[i].second, addr);
    2434                 :             :     }
    2435                 :           0 : }

    2562                 :             :                 // This avoids hurting performance by pointlessly requiring a round-trip
    2563                 :             :                 // Note that there is currently no way for a node to request any single transactions we didn't send here -
    2564                 :             :                 // they must either disconnect and retry or request the full block.
    2565                 :             :                 // Thus, the protocol spec specified allows for us to provide duplicate txn here,
    2566                 :             :                 // however we MUST always provide at least what the remote peer needs

    2572                 :             :             // no response

    2626                 :           0 : void PeerManagerImpl::ProcessGetData(CNode& pfrom, Peer& peer, const std::atomic<bool>& interruptMsgProc)
    2627                 :             : {
    2628                 :           0 :     AssertLockNotHeld(cs_main);
    2629                 :             :

    2631                 :             : 
    2632                 :           0 :     std::deque<CInv>::iterator it = peer.m_getdata_requests.begin();
    2633                 :           0 :     std::vector<CInv> vNotFound;
    2634                 :             : 
    2635                 :             :     // Process as many TX items from the front of the getdata queue as
    2636                 :             :     // possible, since they're common and it's efficient to batch process
    2637                 :             :     // them.
    2638   [ #  #  #  # ]:           0 :     while (it != peer.m_getdata_requests.end() && it->IsGenTxMsg()) {
    2639         [ #  # ]:           0 :         if (interruptMsgProc) return;
    2640                 :             :         // The send buffer provides backpressure. If there's no space in
    2641                 :             :         // the buffer, pause processing until the next call.
    2642         [ #  # ]:           0 :         if (pfrom.fPauseSend) break;
    2643                 :             : 
    2644                 :           0 :         const CInv &inv = *it++;
    2645                 :             :

    2648                 :             :             // peers and peers that asked us not to announce transactions.
    2649                 :           0 :             continue;

    2660                 :             :         }
    2661                 :           0 :     }
    2662                 :             :

    2664                 :             :     // expensive to process.

    2666                 :           0 :         const CInv &inv = *it++;
    2667         [ #  # ]:           0 :         if (inv.IsGenBlkMsg()) {
    2668         [ #  # ]:           0 :             ProcessGetBlockData(pfrom, peer, inv);
    2669                 :             :         }

    2672                 :             :     }
    2673                 :             : 
    2674                 :           0 :     peer.m_getdata_requests.erase(peer.m_getdata_requests.begin(), it);
    2675                 :             : 
    2676         [ #  # ]:           0 :     if (!vNotFound.empty()) {
    2677                 :             :         // Let the peer know that we didn't find what it asked for, so it doesn't
    2678                 :             :         // have to wait around forever.
    2679                 :             :         // SPV clients care about this message: it's needed when they are
    2680                 :             :         // recursively walking the dependencies of relevant unconfirmed
    2681                 :             :         // transactions. SPV clients want to do that because they want to know
    2682                 :             :         // about (and store and rebroadcast and risk analyze) the dependencies
    2683                 :             :         // of transactions relevant to them, without having to download the
    2684                 :             :         // entire memory pool.
    2685                 :             :         // Also, other nodes can use these messages to automatically request a
    2686                 :             :         // transaction from some other peer that announced it, and stop
    2687                 :             :         // waiting for us to respond.
    2688                 :             :         // In normal operation, we often send NOTFOUND messages for parents of
    2689                 :             :         // transactions that we relay; if a peer is missing a parent, they may
    2690                 :             :         // assume we have them and request the parents from us.
    2691   [ #  #  #  # ]:           0 :         MakeAndPushMessage(pfrom, NetMsgType::NOTFOUND, vNotFound);

    2734                 :           0 : arith_uint256 PeerManagerImpl::GetAntiDoSWorkThreshold()
    2735                 :             : {
    2736                 :           0 :     arith_uint256 near_chaintip_work = 0;
    2737                 :           0 :     LOCK(cs_main);
    2738   [ #  #  #  #  :           0 :     if (m_chainman.ActiveChain().Tip() != nullptr) {
                   #  # ]
    2739   [ #  #  #  # ]:           0 :         const CBlockIndex *tip = m_chainman.ActiveChain().Tip();
    2740                 :             :         // Use a 144 block buffer, so that we'll accept headers that fork from
    2741                 :             :         // near our tip.
    2742   [ #  #  #  #  :           0 :         near_chaintip_work = tip->nChainWork - std::min<arith_uint256>(144*GetBlockProof(*tip), tip->nChainWork);

    2744   [ #  #  #  #  :           0 :     return std::max(near_chaintip_work, m_chainman.MinimumChainWork());

    2778                 :             :         }
    2779                 :           0 :         hashLastBlock = header.GetHash();
    2780                 :             :     }

    2784                 :           0 : bool PeerManagerImpl::IsContinuationOfLowWorkHeadersSync(Peer& peer, CNode& pfrom, std::vector<CBlockHeader>& headers)
    2785                 :             : {
    2786         [ #  # ]:           0 :     if (peer.m_headers_sync) {
    2787                 :           0 :         auto result = peer.m_headers_sync->ProcessNextHeaders(headers, headers.size() == m_opts.max_headers_result);
    2788                 :             :         // If it is a valid continuation, we should treat the existing getheaders request as responded to.
    2789         [ #  # ]:           0 :         if (result.success) peer.m_last_getheaders_timestamp = {};
    2790         [ #  # ]:           0 :         if (result.request_more) {
    2791         [ #  # ]:           0 :             auto locator = peer.m_headers_sync->NextHeadersRequestLocator();

    2793         [ #  # ]:           0 :             Assume(!locator.vHave.empty());
    2794                 :             :             // We can only be instructed to request more if processing was successful.
    2795         [ #  # ]:           0 :             Assume(result.success);
    2796         [ #  # ]:           0 :             if (!locator.vHave.empty()) {
    2797                 :             :                 // It should be impossible for the getheaders request to fail,
    2798                 :             :                 // because we just cleared the last getheaders timestamp.
    2799         [ #  # ]:           0 :                 bool sent_getheaders = MaybeSendGetHeaders(pfrom, locator, peer);

    2804                 :           0 :         }

    2866                 :           0 : bool PeerManagerImpl::TryLowWorkHeadersSync(Peer& peer, CNode& pfrom, const CBlockIndex* chain_start_header, std::vector<CBlockHeader>& headers)

    2868                 :             :     // Calculate the claimed total work on this chain.
    2869                 :           0 :     arith_uint256 total_work = chain_start_header->nChainWork + CalculateClaimedHeadersWork(headers);

    2876                 :             :     // are part of a chain with sufficient work.
    2877         [ #  # ]:           0 :     if (total_work < minimum_chain_work) {
    2878                 :             :         // Only try to sync with this peer if their headers message was full;
    2879                 :             :         // otherwise they don't have more headers after this so no point in

    2885                 :             :             // ProcessHeadersMessage() already handles the case where all

    2937                 :             : 
    2938                 :             : /*
    2939                 :             :  * Given a new headers tip ending in last_header, potentially request blocks towards that tip.

    2941                 :             :  * our current tip to be "close to synced" (see CanDirectFetch()).

    3143                 :             :

    3145                 :             :     // m_best_header or our tip, skip anti-DoS checks. These headers will not

    3150                 :           0 :         LOCK(cs_main);

    3170                 :             :         // should be no headers to process any further.

    3172                 :           0 :         return;
    3173                 :             :     }

    3222         [ #  # ]:           0 :     if (state.GetResult() == TxValidationResult::TX_MISSING_INPUTS) {
    3223                 :             :         return;
    3224         [ #  # ]:           0 :     } else if (state.GetResult() != TxValidationResult::TX_WITNESS_STRIPPED) {
    3225                 :             :         // We can add the wtxid of this transaction to our reject filter.
    3226                 :             :         // Do not add txids of witness transactions or witness-stripped
    3227                 :             :         // transactions to the filter, as they can have been malleated;
    3228                 :             :         // adding such txids to the reject filter would potentially
    3229                 :             :         // interfere with relay of valid transactions from peers that
    3230                 :             :         // do not support wtxid-based relay. See
    3231                 :             :         // https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/8279 for details.
    3232                 :             :         // We can remove this restriction (and always add wtxids to
    3233                 :             :         // the filter even for witness stripped transactions) once
    3234                 :             :         // wtxid-based relay is broadly deployed.
    3235                 :             :         // See also comments in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/18044#discussion_r443419034
    3236                 :             :         // for concerns around weakening security of unupgraded nodes
    3237                 :             :         // if we start doing this too early.
    3238         [ #  # ]:           0 :         if (state.GetResult() == TxValidationResult::TX_RECONSIDERABLE) {
    3239                 :             :             // If the result is TX_RECONSIDERABLE, add it to m_lazy_recent_rejects_reconsiderable
    3240                 :             :             // because we should not download or submit this transaction by itself again, but may
    3241                 :             :             // submit it as part of a package later.

    3243                 :             :         } else {

    3245                 :             :         }
    3246                 :           0 :         m_txrequest.ForgetTxHash(ptx->GetWitnessHash());
    3247                 :             :         // If the transaction failed for TX_INPUTS_NOT_STANDARD,
    3248                 :             :         // then we know that the witness was irrelevant to the policy
    3249                 :             :         // failure, since this check depends only on the txid
    3250                 :             :         // (the scriptPubKey being spent is covered by the txid).
    3251                 :             :         // Add the txid to the reject filter to prevent repeated
    3252                 :             :         // processing of this transaction in the event that child
    3253                 :             :         // transactions are later received (resulting in
    3254                 :             :         // parent-fetching by txid via the orphan-handling logic).
